title: If something can not be proven to be true, can it potentially be false? - Quora

response.answer_text: Everything can potentially be false at any time. However, with regards to the standards of a scientific model of the world, nothing is considered existent until (a) you prove it’s there, (b) you prove it’s not something else, and (c) you demonstrate that its existence is capable of predicting future occurrences or phenomena. For instance, if I want to demonstrate that rain is the product of the water cycle instead of Zeus’ mercy, I first observe rain over a long period of time so as to record the pattern it follows, I demonstrate that this pattern does not follow arbitrary whims or respond to prayers and therefore cannot be the work of a capricious, arbitrary god such as Zeus, and then I use the water cycle to predict when it will rain next and how much water will fall (an impossible feat if I’m wrong, given that a characteristically jealous god like Zeus would itch to prove me wrong by forcing rain out of its patterns). Technically, in that example, the burden of proof is on the people claiming that Zeus makes rain, because I would be trying to refute a claim that was never proven to begin with. However, the introduction of the scientific standard model often requires a demonstration of its merits to be accepted, and therefore you would willingly take the burden of proof onto your shoulders so as to perform one. Also, ‘can not be proven’ is more or less a meaningless term in science. It may well be that people in the future will find a way to prove something true. Unless you have reason to believe that the problem is unfalsifiable, that the explanation inherently has no conceivable experiment with which one could potentially demonstrate truth, in which case that problem falls outside the realm of science by definition (because an explanation needs to have a potential testing method in order to be considered scientifically verified) and straight-up doesn’t count.

Question originally answered: If something can not be proven to be true, can it potentially be false?  But of course. One thing that we do know about false propositions is they cannot be demonstrated to be true, so being unable to prove something true, is a sign that one should at least consider that it might be false. Now of course it does matter in which context this question is being asked. Are we talking about some claim Joe Blow made to you while drunk at the bar last night or are we talking about some proposition in a formal system of logic. If we are talking about informal claims, then the methods at our disposal to decide the matter are different than when it concerns a formal proposition in logic. In the informal case we can, beg, steal and borrow, trick, cajole, manipulate and if necessary even coerce. None of these are possible in the case of formal logic. Here we have only two possibilities, given your presumption that the proposition cannot be proven true: The proposition can be proven false, and in that case, it is of course false.The proposition cannot be proven false. In this case the proposition is called undecidable. Whether or not it is actually true depends on the specific model you choose to evaluate the proposition in. In some models it will be a true statement in others false.

Certainly, unless it defies the laws of physics. But you must first understand the difference between possible and probable. The first could be anything from, say, a 30% chance right out to trillions to one against. I have a suspicion that your question is related to the question of the existence or otherwise of God. Most Atheists will say they cannot prove God does not exist, so it is possible, but they will add that the odds are so long they discount the possibility. In my case I believe that Genesis has been proven false and so the Abrahamic God does not exist. I can’t speak for Thor or Zeus but for them I revert to the standard atheist response. The chance is so small as to be easily disregarded.

One sometimes hears claims such as, “No one can prove definitively that ghosts exist, so I have concluded that they do not exist.” Similar claims are heard about God, extraterrestials, and the Lock Ness Monster. This is an old type of inference that was already common when Aristotle was writing about logic. He identified such inferences as fallacious, and subsequent logicians named them Argumentum ad Ignorantiam (argument from ignorance). The logic of this fallacy is that no valid inference can be made from a position of no knowledge. It is a permutation of the dictum ex nihilo, nihil fit (from nothing, nothing comes). So, can a claim that cannot be proven true be potentially false? Yes, but one cannot validly claim that it is definitely false.

Depends what you mean by “possible”. I cannot prove that a car cannot travel at 3,000 mph. Does this mean that it’s possible for a car to travel at 3,000 mph? Yes, the laws of physics don’t disallow this as a possibility.No - there is no car that I can buy or build that will go that fast…it’s impossible.The word “possible” is dangerously vague in this context. You can say this: Just because something has not yet been proven false …doesn’t mean that it will not be proven false sometime in the future.…doesn’t mean that it’s true.…doesn’t confer a statistical probability of either true or false.…does mean that it’s not impossible that it could be found to be true eventually.

Not everything is possible, and something being possible doesn’t make it certain. To use a common example of flawed understanding of possibility, here’s a theoretical conversation that has happened in reality millions of times, except I added a more interesting ending. Person 1 “It cannot be proven that God is impossible, correct?” Person 2 “Correct.” Person 1 “And that means that God must be possible, correct?” Person 2 “Well yes, the statement is technically correct, but it is correct in the same way as aliens are sasquatch are possible.” Person 1 “Ahah, so now that I have gotten you to admit God is possible, you must listen to a long boring story that seems to imply I have special knowledge of why God is a certainty instead of a possibility.” Person 2 “Oh wow, you are totally correct. God just told me that I am His Chosen One! Take me to your leader.” Person 1 “No. That is the devil telling you that.” Person 2 “But you have to admit it’s possible it’s God” Person 1 “No I don’t.”

Yes. It might also be true but unprovable. See Gödel's incompleteness theorems - Wikipedia for an explanation of how this might be true in a very strict sense. In other cases, it might be simply lacking a known proof of either its truth or falsehood. It's also impossible to prove a negative, so if the “something" in question is a negative proposition (e.g. unicorns do not exist), it is not possible to prove (it's possible that a unicorn exists somewhere you just haven't checked yet), though it is possible to refute (e.g. by finding a unicorn).

Sure. Say I have a hypothesis that every time I shout “I want a free hamburger,” I’ll get a free hamburger. Now, say I shout it, and I get a free hamburger. That’s cool. But it doesn’t prove that it’ll always happen. Even if it happens 100 times in a row, I can never prove that it will happen again that way. Now, say on the 101st time, I don’t get a free hamburger. I’ve just disproved my hypothesis. So, it is entirely possible to disprove something that could never be proven.

Of course it can. Firstly, if you can’t prove it to be true, there is already a problem with its quality. Secondly, it can be true or false, at least until there is some kind of evidence to back up one thesis. But even how to prove a thing is a difficult too define. Some philosophers, on the empiristic side, argued that if A gives B one, one hundred, one thousand or millions of time, that is not enough to build a rock solid hypothesis, because can be only accidental that A→B. In the million and 1 test, we could potentially get A→C. You can visualize the answer to your question better if you think to a little elf that wakes up you in the morning. He’s so small that you can’t see him, but in theory he could and could not be there if you do not prove or disprove his existence as your morning alarm.

No, it means nothing of the sort. I can claim that it is possible for purple polka-dotted monkeys to spontaneously spring forth from my nose and dance a Charleston while levitating above my head. The fact that you cannot prove that claim to be false does not mean it is possible. The thing is this: it is impossible to prove a negative. Any negative. It does not therefore follow that everything imaginable is therefore possible. Logic doesn’t work that way.

Does the fact that something has not been proven to be false mean that it is possible? Yes, but that doesn't make it probable. It's an argument found quite often coming from theists, that nobody has disproved gods, so gods are possible, and thereby the religion of the believer making the claim that their god or gods are real, assume that they were right all along. They always fail to disprove the gods they reject, or to substantiate the god/s they accept. The most common iteration is: absence of evidence is not evidence of absence. I usually counter with: absence of evidence is not evidence of presence either. The burden of proof lies with the original claim, if you can't disprove a claim, it does not automatically follow that said claim is true.

“Does the fact that something has not been proven to be false mean that it is possible?” Well, depends on your definition of “possible”. You could argue that anything is possible, even that you will suddenly turn into a slimy monster with an insatiable appetite for cookies. And I’d agree - after all, it’s possible that we all just live in a computer simulation, or that I am the only one who really exists and everyone else is just my imagination. And lest you think I’m making fun of you, I’m not - there are plenty of philosophical debates on such possibilities. But while everything is theoretically possible, not everything is probable in practice. If you make a statement which defies the laws of physics, for example, it’s highly improbable to be true. If you believe something extraordinary will happen but have no rational argument for it, it’s improbable that people will take it seriously. And yet, many things we take for granted today were once believed to be impossible. The scientific method keeps pushing the boundaries of our knowledge and capabilities, so sometimes pursuing the impossible might well be worth it!

Everything that can be tested, was tested, and not proven false, is probably true. A simple example, the curvature of space caused by presence of mass. It was proposed as one of the implications of the Theory of Relativity: mass curves space. It was tested, and the measurement obtained was cross-referenced with other possible causes. They could not show it to be false, so our confidence in this theory became higher. Now, a counter-example. “God exists” cannot be tested, according to the proponents of “God exists”. You must accept it by faith. So it’s up to you. I would say that anything that can be proposed without evidence can be dismissed without evidence. God doesn’t exist, because all proponents haven’t shown any evidence that it’s not a figment of their imagination.

yes, for example one of the alkali metals is impossible to separate, but it may be possible in the future if we travel to another planet where it may exist. it may be impossible in this world but not on another planet. also there is a theory of a multiverse. this theory suggests that whatever happens in this universe, the complete opposite will happen on another universe. So i decided to answer this question in this universe; in another universe i don’t instead i do something else. so something can be impossible in this universe but possible in another universe. Also we don’t have the technology to do certain tasks. however, the tasks we are not able to do now, we may be able to do in the future when we create advanced technology which are able to perform certain tasks which are regarded as impossible currently. or we might meet aliens who possess such technology so in simple terms YES

The God’s existence is very true but none of us in this century can prove it.  It only know through the trust and have a faith in God and its belief.  Some people may experience the God’s appearance in different form rather than what we have an image of him but it is happening all over the world.  We just don’t believe it is happening.  God may show up as a dog, bird, or man or woman appearance and help people as they need a help.  God uses people to accomplish certain things and you yourself may be used by God in some things.  God is very clever and brilliant superior being that he is beyond our human comprehension.  Never to take God’s words lightly…

Everything is “possible” unless it violates the laws of physics. And since physics has been wrong before, and could be wrong currently, even things that violate the laws of physics are still “possible”, given suitable changes to the laws. So it turns out that “possible” isn’t really a very useful word in these situations - if literally everything you can imagine is possible, then the word has no real use.

Technically, yes. I'll use atheism as an example (and I'm NOT picking on atheists, some of my closest friends are atheist, it's just an excellent example). The existence of God has not been proven true or false, therefore the existence of God is entirely possible. The atheist has decided to reject something unproven and by doing so rejects an actual possibility. I totally get why an atheist would do this, especially given the ridiculous and horrifying smorgasbord of religions this world offers, but they are rejecting something that could be true. Which is totally up to them and they are free to do.

If we can’t prove something to be true, then it is false, which is proven to be true.If we can’t prove something to be false, then it is true, which is proven to be false.If the argument is neither proven nor disproven, then the system itself is flawed or inconsistent.If we are dumb, then we are clever, which is somewhat stupid.

No. If you list in two groups, all the things that could be possible, and all the things that could not be possible, then we can also group both sets by those that have been proven, and those than have not. Clearly, those facts that have not been proven, will include some that are possible, and some that are not.

It depends on how we define ‘possible’. If something has not been proven to be false, that does not prove that it is necessarily possible in objective terms. However, it is permissible for our minds to entertain the idea that it may be possible, subject to further information.

Potentially is the operative word here. Your Mom’s cooking isn’t true, nor is it false. It just …is <adjective here>. Whether you enjoyed it or not is also subjective/qualitative and is not correct. Nor is it false. I struggle with Philosophy and nonsensical questions.

No one has ever proved that there is a God. Doesn’t mean it can’t be done, only that it has NOT been done, yet. Nothing follows from that either way, it is not the case that it is false because nobody has proved it. It is a case of ‘ we don’t know the answer right now, so let us wait until it has been found’ Hope that helps

YES If something is impossible, it has many factors which cause it to be impossible. however, if those factors are effected on a huge scale causing a change in them then it could possibly change the “impossible” into “possible”. for example right now it is impossible to separate one of the alkali metals, however, in the far future we might meet aliens with the technology or create the technology ourselves to separate this metal. Thank you for the brilliant question! and no i’m not a 11 year old kid with a pharaoh profile picture and a Greek god name!

Yes it can. Another way of putting it is just because something hasn’t been proved to be impossible it cannot be presumed that it’s therefore possible. It may be & it may not be. We cannot know but we may be able to make a reasoned guess.

The key word missing is “could”, meaning it could be possible (not is, because of all the unknowns). As long as “proven to be false” includes proven to be false because it violates the known demonstrable laws of the universe and not has been directly proven to be false.

If something can not be proven to be true, can it potentially be false? ~~~ “For every Perspective, there is an equal and opposite Perspective!” - First Law of Soul Dynamics For every ‘true’ there is a ‘false’; Heads and Tails still = One Coin! *__-
Things are possible even if ‘proven’ to be ‘false.’ Proof is constructed. Perception itself is culturally constructed. ‘Reality’ is subjective. (The Trump election proves that.)

Fun question. I think this ventures more into philosophy, though. Concerning, say, gravity: I would say that it has been proven (and therefore exists and is therefore = true), but it is still considered to be the theory of gravity. It could very well be that it is one day proven to be something other than what we know it to be at a later time. So I would say it’s hard to use simple true/false for something along those lines. So I will use a software engineering term and call it truthy and falsey. Gravity is truthy. Defining pure true and false is an extremely detailed subject matter, I think.

Does the fact that something has not been proven to be false mean that it is possible? I can't prove that time travel isn't possible. Therefore, time travel exists as a concept, especially in science fiction scenarios. However, it doesn't mean that time travel is possible. It very likely defies the laws of physics.
1+1=5 can't be proven to be true as it is false, so of course it is possible
Nothing can be considered possible until proven to be possible.That it’s not been proven false (yet), just means that it might be possible, not that it is possible.

There is a saying in physics that anything not strictly forbidden, must exist. This is mainly a comment on the vastness of the universe. We might not have unicorns here on earth, but they might exist somewhere. Note that supernatural magic beings are ruled out by the laws of nature.
Of course. Consider the proposition “1=0”. It is not possible to show the proposition to be true, and in fact the proposition is false.
Argument from ignorance - Wikipedia
All that it means is that something has not been proven false. Which also leaves open the possibility that the concept needs to be rethought or that it may be true.
No, it only means that it may be possible, not that it is possible. There is an important distinction there.
No, it means that it may not be impossible.
Yes. It may be indeterminate.
Yes, and no.
Yes.
